newsitem.title: UK: Metals Outlook--Aluminium, options in spotlight.
newsitem.headline: Metals Outlook--Aluminium, options in spotlight.

text.p: The metals markets are expected to zero in on aluminium this week when London Metal Exchange (LME) options are declared.
Eyes will also be on zinc as players nervously watch for any signs of aftershocks from the plunge from seven-year highs last week.
Three months aluminium surged to a 21-month high of $1,740 last Friday as a squeeze in the August date, said to be linked to options, constricted the market.
Funds and investment banks leapt in and help fuelled the move while consumers were said to be holding back, waiting for a dip as physical premiums held firm.
The next upside target was said to be the November 1995 peak of $1,745, but some analysts said the market was overbought and needed a rest.
The 14-day RSI ended last week at 81, well above the 70 region regarded as overbought.
"I'm a bit wary on how much the upside can do," said analyst Martin Squires of broker Rudolf Wolff.
"I'm still overall bullish on the market and while it trends you should stick with it, but just beware it's getting to the point where you might see some profit taking," he added.
The cash/three months spread flipped into a modest backwardation last week.
Some traders said a big player who was short of options had to cover the position by borrowing in the futures market.
The LME options declaration on Wednesday could spark interest in aluminium, with grantors said to be short above the $1,700 strike.
With large chunks of options open interest above the market in forward months, there are good prospects for more delta hedging to kick in.
The $1,700 strike in call options is the focus, with 1,555 lots in August, 2,452 lots in September, 3,174 lots in October and 2,166 lots in November.

In zinc, a nervous market was still unsure how much more covering had to be done by Chinese smelters, but tightness was still being felt, with the cash/threes spread ending last week at a $76/$86 backwardation.
Some players believe the three months will remain relatively stable after its $300 plunge to a low of $1,370 last week, and action will shift to the spreads.
"The longs have sold the three months but they've kept the (September) date. So the market is open to another squeeze at some point before September," one trader said.
"I think China has enough zinc, but they haven't got the right dates," he added.

Squires said he believed three months could make a move up to $1,500 or $1,530 this week as short-covering continues. China appears to have rolled some of its position forward while some consumers may need to enter the market, he said.
Copper was less active last week as the backwardation contracted, with the cash/threes ending the week at $30/$35.
Three months, which ended Friday at $2,310, would try to consolidate above $2,300, but with stocks expected to keep rising, tests of the downside were expected eventually, analysts said.
